dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, B. So, uh, we've been seeing a lot of chatter lately about Sovereign Wealth Funds, right? Their investment strategies seem to be, well, shifting quite a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, B. So, uh, we've been seeing a lot of chatter lately about Sovereign Wealth Funds, right? Their investment strategies seem to be, well, shifting quite a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, definitely. I just saw this report, and it's pretty wild. Like, after some really successful years, their total assets under management actually *plummeted* to $7.4 trillion back in 2016. That's a huge drop.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, definitely. I just saw this report, and it's pretty wild. Like, after some really successful years, their total assets under management actually plummeted to seven point four trillion dollars back in twenty sixteen. That's a huge drop.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...total assets under management still grew to US$7.4 trillion in 2016, albeit at a slower pace than prior years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's kind of counter-intuitive, especially with some of the earlier success they had. But it seems to be driving them to, uh, really narrow down their investment strategies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's kind of counter-intuitive, especially with some of the earlier success they had. But it seems to be driving them to, uh, really narrow down their investment strategies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. They're like, stepping away from non-fossil sources, and really just focusing on, you know, more traditional investments. I guess to kind of, um, stabilize things?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. They're like, stepping away from non-fossil sources, and really just focusing on, you know, more traditional investments. I guess to kind of, um, stabilize things?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's what it sounds like. And you can see it in the numbers, too. Like, their investment into fixed income instruments, things like government bonds, has really shot up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's what it sounds like. And you can see it in the numbers, too. Like, their investment into fixed income instruments, things like government bonds, has really shot up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SWF investment into fixed income instruments such as government bonds has dropped from a peak of 40% in 2013 to 30% in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. And with all these expected interest rate cuts, especially in Europe and the US, it's really pushing SWFs to seek out even lower yields, isn't it? They're basically just reallocating away from those, uh, non-traditional areas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. And with all these expected interest rate cuts, especially in Europe and the U S, it's really pushing S W Fs to seek out even lower yields, isn't it? They're basically just reallocating away from those, uh, non-traditional areas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report acknowledges expected interest rate hikes across Europe and the United States but predicts they will be moderate, encouraging SWFs to continue searching for yield by allocating investment to non-traditional areas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a big move. Now, about those alternative asset classes, the report does mention that most of them are actually pretty liquid, which is interesting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a big move. Now, about those alternative asset classes, the report does mention that most of them are actually pretty liquid, which is interesting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report notes that including certain alternative asset classes is not without risks as the majority of alternatives are highly illiquid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Yeah, most are, but then you've got like, gold, which is a big exception, right? Super low daily volumes, so it can't really protect against those short-term market corrections.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, most are, but then you've got like, gold, which is a big exception, right? Super low daily volumes, so it can't really protect against those short-term market corrections.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An exception is gold, which has one of the highest rates of daily volumes exchanged and can provide protection against short and medium term market corrections.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And Will Jackson-Moore from PwC, he weighed in on this, saying he expects alternatives to be, um, "non-existent" in SWF portfolios in the future.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And Will Jackson-Moore from P w C, he weighed in on this, saying he expects alternatives to be, um, non-existent in S W F portfolios in the future.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We expect alternatives to be prominent in SWF portfolios in the future as they can offer increased diversification, principal protection, a hedge against inflation, and an increase in portfolio performance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, I mean, makes sense if they're seeing decreased diversification and, uh, principal vulnerability from them. So they're kinda just like, ditching them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, I mean, makes sense if they're seeing decreased diversification and, uh, principal vulnerability from them. So they're kinda just like, ditching them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We expect alternatives to be prominent in SWF portfolios in the future as they can offer increased diversification, principal protection, a hedge against inflation, and an increase in portfolio performance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, here's where it gets a little muddled. He also said that including *certain* alternatives might actually eliminate risks like illiquidity. So, it's not a complete no-go for everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, here's where it gets a little muddled. He also said that including certain alternatives might actually eliminate risks like illiquidity. So, it's not a complete no-go for everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...including certain alternatives might introduce a new set of risks such as illiquidity, complexity, and cyclicality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh, so it's not totally black and white, then. But, um, overall, it sounds like the sentiment is that the losses from alternatives generally outweigh any potential gains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh, so it's not totally black and white, then. But, um, overall, it sounds like the sentiment is that the losses from alternatives generally outweigh any potential gains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overall though, the benefits seem to outweigh the costs, as the varied nature of alternatives provides SWFs with the ability to select an asset class specific to their investment needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the takeaway. The uniform nature of many alternatives just doesn't allow SWFs to pick something super specific to their needs, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the takeaway. The uniform nature of many alternatives just doesn't allow S W Fs to pick something super specific to their needs, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overall though, the benefits seem to outweigh the costs, as the varied nature of alternatives provides SWFs with the ability to select an asset class specific to their investment needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, we're basically seeing a big pivot back to, uh, safety and traditional assets for these massive funds. Less risk, maybe lower reward, but more stability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we're basically seeing a big pivot back to, uh, safety and traditional assets for these massive funds. Less risk, maybe lower reward, but more stability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. It's a fascinating shift in how these huge funds are managing, uh, billions of dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It's a fascinating shift in how these huge funds are managing, uh, billions of dollars.

dialogue_turns.text: Definitely something to keep an eye on.
